name: ESP PMU or Zone reporting
description: ESP PMU or Zone reporting description

items.source: Please complete the reporting for your PMU site below.

items.preLabel: Please confirm the 12 month period that this report covers

sections.name: ESP Livestock Grazing Management
sections.description:
1. Reducing the ability of exotic annual plant species to set seed and vegetation biomass
2. Facilitating seed set by native perennials and promoting regeneration of native plants;
3. Reducing soil disturbance and compaction caused by hard-hooved domestic livestock;
4. Reducing selective grazing of palatable native perennial plants;
5. Reducing nutrient input through animal excrement.

Please note Grazing activities may also be included under “Conservation grazing”, “Strategic grazing”, “Monitoring and manage grazing pressure from domestic livestock” and “Monitor and manage total grazing pressure”.
Endeavour to record sward height and ground cover percentage prior to and after each grazing period.
sections.collapsibleHeading: What are the conservation outcomes sought?
sections.optionalQuestionText: Not an agreed management action under my funding agreement

items.source:
What are the conservation outcomes sought?
1) Reducing the ability of exotic annual plant species to set seed and vegetation biomass
2) Facilitating seed set by native perennials and promoting regeneration of native plants;
3) Reducing soil disturbance and compaction caused by hard-hooved domestic livestock;
4) Reducing selective grazing of palatable native perennial plants;
5) Reducing nutrient input through animal excrement.

Please note Grazing activities may also be included under “Conservation grazing”, “Strategic grazing”, “Monitoring and manage grazing pressure from domestic livestock” and “Monitor and manage total grazing pressure”.
Endeavour to record sward height and ground cover percentage prior to and after each grazing period.

items.preLabel: Was this activity undertaken during this reporting period?
Is this site divided up into multiple paddocks?
Is grazing exclusion a management action in your funding agreement?

items.title: Please record all grazing periods for this site:

items.source:
• the impact of weeds on native trees, saplings/seedlings, native grasses and forbs
  • any unusual circumstances that occurred whilst grazing (e.g. fencing damaged so stock spread to different area; increase in feral animals or native herbivores near the site whilst stock present; issues with stock removal due to conditions)
  • if you grazed on dates outside the set grazing limits outlined in the management actions please provide an explanation and indicate if you have informed the Department via email/phone, as required
  • would changes to the permitted grazing dates have a more positive impact on the site’s environment?
  • any additional comments or observations.

items.preLabel: Total cost of management actions:
items.helpText: These costs can include, but are not limited to: cost of time taken to move stock or cost to repair fences and infrastructure damaged.

items.preLabel: If you did not undertake this activity during this reporting period, but it is a Management Action under your Funding Agreement, please state the reason:

sections.title: Livestock Grazing Management

sections.name: ESP Sward Height
sections.collapsibleHeading: What are the conservation outcomes sought?
sections.optionalQuestionText: Not applicable, as this is not a contracted (approved) management action for this site/management unit.

template.description: To measure sward height, find a spot on your site that is representative of the site. Use either a ruler or eyeball a measurement of the sward height. If using a ruler, place the base on the surface of the soil. Slide your thumb down until you touch the top of the leaf blade. Do not measure the stems or flower heads.
template.title: Sward Height

items.source:
Record sward height at the same time that you take the photo-point photograph for this site. Please ensure that this is done at the same time each year.
You can find instructions on measuring Sward height here: Measuring Sward height - DCCEEW
You can include an image of the sward height as a way to enhance records of the impact of the Environmental Stewardship Program.

sections.title: ESP Sward Height

sections.name: ESP Ground Cover
sections.collapsibleHeading: What are the conservation outcomes sought?
sections.optionalQuestionText: Not applicable, as this is not a contracted (approved) management action for this site/management unit.

template.description: Ground cover is the plant material covering the ground, both living and dead. To get a % estimate stand with your feet about 50cm apart. Visualise a 50cm square in front of your feet and estimate the percentage of groundcover in it. Do this a few times across the site and average the results.
template.title: Ground Cover Percentage (%) Estimate

items.source:
Record ground cover % at the same time that you take the photo-point photograph for this site. Please ensure that this is done at the same time each year.
You can find instructions on measuring Ground cover here: Estimating ground cover percentage - DCCEEW
You can include an image of the ground cover as a way to enhance records of the impact of the Environmental Stewardship Program.

sections.title: Ground Cover %

sections.name: ESP Native herbivore management
sections.description:
1. Reducing browsing impact on palatable native plants;
2. Maintaining native species diversity and facilitating natural regeneration;
3. Reducing overgrazing, thus weed infestation; and
4. Improving litter and soil condition.

Implementation:
Actions that involve reduction in the native herbivore numbers include:
  • exclusion is best carried out with a 3-strand plain wire fence affixed to the top of a stock-proof fence
  • trapping and relocation, but only under licence
  • enticement away from the site (e.g. through strategic placement of watering points), the success of which would need to be monitored
  • culling of native herbivores, which can only be conducted with the authorisation of and a license issued by the appropriate government authority
Please note ideally culling should be coordinated with other similar actions in the region in order to maximise impact, and undertaken in a humane manner consistent with legislative requirements.

Please note Activities to monitor and/or manage native herbivores may also be included under “Monitor and manage total grazing pressure”, “Monitor and manage grazing pressure from native species” or “Monitor and manage native herbivores.”
sections.collapsibleHeading: What are the conservation outcomes sought?
sections.optionalQuestionText: Not an agreed management action under my funding agreement

template.description: When you enter the details for this activity please make sure that you only enter the number and cost details once. Either as a single total record, encompassing the details and costs of this activity across all of your sites or as separate entries for each site.
template.title: Native Herbivore Management

items.source:
What are the conservation outcomes sought?
1. Reducing browsing impact on palatable native plants;
2. Maintaining native species diversity and facilitating natural regeneration;
3. Reducing overgrazing, thus weed infestation; and
4. Improving litter and soil condition.

Implementation:
Actions that involve reduction in the native herbivore numbers include:
Exclusion is best carried out with a 3-strand plain wire fence affixed to the top of a stock-proof fence.
Trapping and relocation is an option for native herbivores, but only under licence.

Enticement away from the site (e.g. through strategic placement of watering points) is also an option, but success would need to be monitored.

Culling of native herbivores, which can only be conducted with the authorisation of and a license issued by the appropriate government authority. Ideally, culling should be coordinated with other similar actions in the region in order to maximise impact, and would be undertaken in a humane manner consistent with conservation and land stewardship values.

Please note Activities to monitor and/or manage native herbivores may also be included under “Monitor and manage total grazing pressure”, “Monitor and manage grazing pressure from native species” or “Monitor and manage native herbivores.”

items.preLabel: Was this activity undertaken during this reporting period?

items.title: Please complete the following (adding a new row for each different species and each different season you have monitored or managed Herbivores):

items.source:
• the impact of native herbivores on the site on trees seedlings and saplings ; impact on native grasses and flowers. (State if this impact is significant or minimal)
  • damage to infrastructure and soil disturbance
  • is the culling effective or is the population too large?
  • do you see the need for further action?
  • was a permit obtained from NSW National Parks and Wildlife Service to authorise this culling or was it a licenced shooter?
  • any additional comments or observations.

items.preLabel: Total cost of management actions:
items.helpText: These costs can include, but are not limited to: hours steward takes to undertake native herbivore management, ammunition or cost of contractors.

items.preLabel: If you did not undertake this activity this reporting period, but it is an agreed Management Action under your Funding Agreement, please state the reason.

sections.title: Native herbivore management

sections.name: ESP Feral animal management
sections.description:
1.To reduce browsing impact on palatable native plants and local native fauna;
2. Maintain native species diversity and facilitate natural regeneration;
3. Reduce overgrazing leading to weed infestation;
4. Improve litter and soil condition.

Implementation:
Land managers are required to control feral herbivores and carnivores (for example rabbits, hares, goats, deer, pigs, foxes or feral cats) where these are having a detrimental impact on the target ecological community. Control measures will differ between species and may include both preventative (e.g. fencing) and destructive measures as appropriate.
Destructive control measures should minimise unintended adverse impacts on non-target species and be undertaken humanely and in accordance with NSW legislation. Warren ripping to control rabbits within a target ecological community should be undertaken as a last resort and every effort should be taken to minimise soil disturbance away from the immediate warren site.

Please note Activities to monitor and/or manage feral animals may also be included under; “Monitor and manage total grazing pressure” and “Monitor and manage feral animals”.
sections.collapsibleHeading: What are the conservation outcomes sought?
sections.optionalQuestionText: Not an agreed management action under my funding agreement

1.To reduce browsing impact on palatable native plants and local native fauna;

4. Improve litter and soil condition.

Implementation:
Land managers are encouraged to control feral herbivores and carnivores (for example rabbits, hares, goats, deer, pigs, foxes or feral cats) where these are having a detrimental impact on the target ecological community. Control measures will differ between species and may include both preventative (e.g. fencing) and destructive measures as appropriate.
Destructive control measures should minimise unintended adverse impacts on non-target species and be undertaken humanely and in accordance with NSW legislation. Warren ripping to control rabbits within a target ecological community should be undertaken as a last resort and every effort should be taken to minimise soil disturbance away from the immediate warren site.

Please note Activities to monitor and/or manage feral animals may also be included under; “Monitor and manage total grazing pressure” and “Monitor and manage feral animals”.

  • any damage to infrastructure on the property, stating if this impact is significant or minimal

  • if there are significant feral animals in the surrounding properties moving on the ESP site

sections.title: Feral animal management

sections.name: ESP Weed management
sections.description:
1. To reduce exotic plant cover, thereby reducing competition with native plants.
2. To reduce exotic plant biomass.
3. To create more gaps in the ground layer to facilitate regeneration of native groundcover species.

Implementation:
Land managers are required to control weeds through: Strategic grazing and targeted controls including localised application of herbicides (spot spraying, weed wiping), hand pulling or chipping of target weed species, mowing, and slashing or possibly localised conservation burning (under an appropriate management plan and permission from NSW Rural Fire Service as required).

Please note Activities to monitor and/or manage weeds may also be included under any or all of the following; “Monitor and manage herbaceous exotic plants (aggressive)”, “Monitor and manage herbaceous exotic plants (non-aggressive)”, “Monitor and manage exotic shrubs (aggressive)”, “Monitor and manage exotic plants”, “Monitor and manage aggressive exotic plants” and “Monitor and manage non-aggressive exotic plants”.
sections.collapsibleHeading: What are the conservation outcomes sought?
sections.optionalQuestionText: Not an agreed management action under my funding agreement

template.title: Weed Management

items.source:
What are the conservation outcomes sought?
1. to reduce exotic plant cover, thereby reducing competition with native plants;
2. to reduce exotic plant biomass;
3. to create more gaps in the groundlayer to facilitate regeneration of native groundcover species.

Controlled through:
Strategic grazing and targeted controls including localised application of herbicides (spot spraying, weed wiping), hand pulling or chipping of target weed species, mowing, and slashing or possibly localised conservation burning (under an appropriate management plan and permission from relevant agencies as required).

Please note Activities to monitor and/or manage weeds may also be included under any or all of the following; “Monitor and manage herbaceous exotic plants (aggressive)”, “Monitor and manage herbaceous exotic plants (non-aggressive)”, “Monitor and manage exotic shrubs (aggressive)”, “Monitor and manage exotic plants”, “Monitor and manage aggressive exotic plants” and “Monitor and manage non-aggressive exotic plants”.

  • any new weeds occurring on the property that you have not previously seen
  • any additional comments or observations

sections.title: Weed management

sections.name: ESP Biomass control measures
sections.description:
1. Enhancing the diversity of the native ground flora by promoting the growth and spread of other grasses and herbs.

Implementation:
Reducing the density of the dominant perennial species (the biomass) through small scale ecological burns, by strategic grazing or by slashing over relatively small areas at an agreed timing and frequency.

Please note Activities to control Biomass may also be included under “Monitor and manage dominant native species”, “Biomass control to reduce dominance of a single native plant species”, “Biomass Control” and “Thinning”.
sections.collapsibleHeading: What are the conservation outcomes sought?
sections.optionalQuestionText: Not an agreed management action under my funding agreement

template.title: Biomass Control Measures

items.source:
What are the conservation outcomes sought?
1. Enhancing the diversity of the native ground flora by promoting the growth and spread of other grasses and herbs.
2. Implementation through small scale ecological burns, by strategic grazing or by slashing over relatively small areas at an agreed timing and frequency.

Please note Activities to control Biomass may also be included under “Monitor and manage dominant native species”, “Biomass control to reduce dominance of a single native plant species”, “Biomass Control” and “Thinning”.

sections.name: ESP Revegetation
sections.description:
1. Speed up the recovery of the woodland, namely to assist in rehabilitating stock camps;
2. Re-introducing of locally rare endemic plants;
3. Re-introducing of trees into large areas of derived grassland or degraded woodland;
4. Provide competition to established or vigorous weed species.

Please note that revegetation activities may also be included under; “Re-establish perennial native species”, “Plants overstorey tree species of target community”, “Re-establish understorey shrubs”, “Plant perennial species” and “Planting/direct seeding”.

sections.title: Revegetation

sections.name: ESP Regeneration
sections.description:
1. Establish mature and immature examples of the dominant eucalypt species and understory.
2. Improve the structural diversity, cover and shelter for woodland birds and other animals, increasing the available foraging potential and maintenance of the woodland overstorey in the long term.

Implementation
Removal of grazing pressure and exotic weed competition can support the regeneration of trees and shrubs. If a remnant tree exists in isolation within a patch (i.e. paddock tree), land managers may consider fencing an area around the tree to encourage natural regeneration.

Please note Activities relating to Regeneration may also be included under any or all of the following; “Monitor and manage regeneration”, “Buffering”, “Connectivity” and “Reduce isolation”.
sections.collapsibleHeading: What are the conservation outcomes sought?
sections.optionalQuestionText: Not an agreed management action under my funding agreement

sections.title: Regeneration

sections.name: ESP Restoration of Habitat Features
sections.description:
1. Tree or substantial branches that fall to the ground it provides a sheltered habitat enabling seeds to germinate and the process of natural regeneration to occur;
2. Fallen branches, rocks and small objects create habitats for native fauna species.

Implementation
Land managers are encouraged to leave fallen trees or branches where they fall within their woodland patch. The use of rocks and other habitat objects like nest boxes, old untreated fence posts and corrugated iron can improve the habitat features of the ESP zone.

Please note Activities to restore habitat features may also be included under “Add coarse woody debris” and “Retain fallen timber”.
